project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: Archaeogenomic study analysing genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning approximately 5400-2400 BC. Investigates the genetic contact and admixture between late Copper Age farming societies and early pastoralist groups from the Eurasian steppes, proposing that early contact between these groups during the fourth millennium BC was integral to the formation of Yamnaya pastoralists around 3300 BC.

evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21).
evidence.notes: Sample breakdown by period: 1 Neolithic, 95 Copper Age, 18 Eneolithic, 21 Early Bronze Age

consolidation_metadata.rationale: E02 contains complete sample breakdown (135/216 attempted, 8 sites, period breakdown) which subsumes E01's general statement

evidence.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×.
We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation and filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses

The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics
evidence.notes: PCA and f3 statistics for earliest individual

evidence.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1) and thus combined them into local group SEE 1, which could be used as a single source for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)
evidence.notes: qpAdm modelling results for Neolithic proxy

evidence.verbatim_quote: In PCA space, the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE
evidence.notes: PCA clustering of Copper Age individuals

evidence.verbatim_quote: Moreover, outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region
evidence.notes: f3 statistics showing CA genetic homogeneity

evidence.verbatim_quote: all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals
Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry.

Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale.

The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry, which could be confirmed by f4 statistics of the form f4(SEE N, PIE060; HGs, Mbuti) ((|Z| ≥ 3); Supplementary Table F).
evidence.notes: Outlier individual with excess HG ancestry

evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies.

Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), which corresponds to around 81–832 years before the mean 14C date of PIE060

With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88), six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88) and four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a), the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes, consistent with previous observation across early farming societies
evidence.notes: ROH analysis indicating large population sizes

evidence.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals from the North Caucasus and Khvalynsk in western Russia
The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years
We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656).
evidence.notes: No temporal correlation in PC2 positions

evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous, with five individuals (Kartal A) forming a cline between 'Steppe Eneolithic'/'Steppe Maykop' individuals and Early Neolithic groups, while three other individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to the latter

The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site (USV/UBK; Supplementary Table A) in the middle of the 'Kartal cline'.
First, compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)
With respect to Steppe Eneolithic, all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all tested CA groups.
Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

Following up with proximal qpAdm models to explore potential contribution(s) of temporally and geographically closer groups (Fig. 3e and Supplementary Tables E and S), we find that all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry.
evidence.notes: Proximal two-way model for Ukraine Eneolithic

evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source.
By contrast, MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component.
evidence.notes: Three-way model for MAJ and USV

evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, to test whether we can distinguish between the farmer-related ancestry contributed by SEE CA- or Maykop-associated groups from the Caucasus, or by both, we rotated each source to the outgroups, alternatingly, keeping Steppe Eneolithic as a constant. Here, we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals (except KTL_B)

The same model is supported for MAJ (P = 0.05) but rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter. Indeed, the competing model, with Maykop as an additional source and VAR_CA as an outgroup, results in a well-fit four-way mixture model for USV (P = 0.93) and improved model fit for MAJ (P = 0.33)

uncertainty.value: P = 0.05 for MAJ (two-way), P = 0.93 for USV, P = 0.33 for MAJ (four-way)

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Sequential model comparisons for same populations consolidated

evidence.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites.
evidence.notes: IBD relationship between MAJ and USV

evidence.verbatim_quote: in comparison to the preceding CA and heterogenous KTL individuals, ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV (Extended Data Fig. 5), suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups.
evidence.notes: ROH indicates smaller population sizes for Usatove

evidence.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources (Extended Data Fig. 3b): G2a is probably a Neolithic legacy, while three males carrying I2a1 could be attributed to the local Ukrainian Neolithic or HG groups in general.

KTL005 and MAJ009 carry haplotypes R1b/M343(×P297) and R1b1/L754(×M269), respectively, which are ancestral for the pre-M269 branch (P297) and the M269 branch. Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry.

The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space (Fig. 1b) and different genetic affinities in outgroup f3 statistics (Fig. 2 and Supplementary Table C).

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium BC, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: we tested for additional attraction towards HG-related groups in YUN_EBA and PIE078 compared to their CA predecessors by using f4(CA, EBA; HGs, Mbuti) and confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.notes: f4 test for HG ancestry in YUN/PIE EBA

evidence.verbatim_quote: Here, only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling with cornerstone populations confirms the contrasting ancestries of the two main EBA clusters. PIE078 and YUN_EBA can be modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG (Fig. 3c and Supplementary Table X), whereas MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019 and YUN041 require EHG ancestry as an additional source

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.notes: Distal modelling confirms EBA cluster differences

evidence.verbatim_quote: With the exception of Yamnaya Caucasus, all EBA individuals show an excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.notes: Three-way model for BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara

evidence.verbatim_quote: We note that the same three sources contributed to the preceding Ukraine Eneolithic individuals from USV and MAJ (in addition to SEE CA ancestry), which suggests that similar processes had led to the tripartite ancestry formation in the steppe zone during the fourth millennium bc.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Indeed, we find that BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001 (who lacked SEE_CA ancestry).

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%)

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, confirming the findings of Lazaridis and colleagues

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: This two-way mix (40% + 60%, respectively) also provides a well-fit model (P = 0.09) for the Ozera outlier individual, consistent with the position in PCA and corroborating an influence from the Caucasus.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

evidence.verbatim_quote: Of the 135 individuals reported in this study we obtained new direct 14C dates for 113 individuals. Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

consolidation_metadata.rationale: E53 provides more methodological detail about radiocarbon dating than E05's brief mention

evidence.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total.

All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment). We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual... and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix, ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%.
evidence.notes: Consolidated aDNA authentication metrics: damage patterns, contamination estimates

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Three related authentication metrics consolidated into single quality profile

evidence.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis.

Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV), while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica.

Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates. However, accounting for this possibility, an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc

we used f4-symmetry statistics of the form f4(steppe1, steppe2; test, Mbuti) where test includes Ukraine N, Ukraine Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Steppe Eneolithic. Here, with the exception of outlier individual Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya, all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) (Supplementary Table W), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc.

from around 4500 bc on, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and those from the forest/steppe zones, indicating genetic and cultural contact over a period of around 1,000 years earlier than anticipated.
claims.notes: Key finding: contact 1000 years earlier than expected

claims.verbatim_quote: what happened between the demise of the Copper Age settlements around 4250 bc and the expansion of pastoralists remains poorly understood
In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites
We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics

outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale.
all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals

Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations

This indicates possible admixture between CA farmer-related groups and Eneolithic steppe groups, as in line with cultural interactions described in the archaeological record
The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years
We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656).
claims.notes: No temporal correlation in genetic variation

The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space (Fig. 1b) and different genetic affinities in outgroup f3 statistics. Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium BC, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex.

all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: The genetic homogeneity observed in and across the four CA sites (PIE, YUN, PTK and VAR) of the fifth millennium bc matches the cultural homogeneity of the archaeological records and suggests an extended period of a relative stable sociopolitical network and absence of large-scale cultural and genetic transformations.

A principal finding from our study indicates early contact and admixture between CA farming groups from SEE and Eneolithic groups from the steppe zone in today's southern Ukraine, possibly starting in the middle of the fifth millennium bc when settlement densities shifted further north, connecting the lower Danube region with the coastal steppe and Cucuteni–Trypillia groups of the forest–steppe.
Despite the close geographical proximity of the Ukrainian sites studied, we were able to trace different admixture histories.

While only a few tell sites have been resettled by local and/or incoming groups who did not originate in the North Pontic region, we can trace the appearance of migrants from the steppe, clearly attributed to Yamnaya culturally and genetically, in the local time transect at Majaky but also at Boyanovo in the Bulgarian lowlands of the Thracian Plain.

EBA individuals from the fourth and third millennia bc from YUN and PIE do not show traces of steppe-like ancestry but instead a resurgence of HG ancestry observed widely in Europe during the fourth millennium bc

Despite the overlap in PCA, these results suggest subtle geographical structure, involving local genetic strata and influences from neighbouring groups in western and southern contact zones, respectively.

location.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.verbatim_quote: Two outlier individuals from EBA YUN and BOY bear witness to occasional admixture between inhabitants of EBA tells and incoming steppe pastoralists.
we caution that genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts, causing the replacement of one CA group by another.

This indicates the presence of remnant HG groups in various non-farmed regions, for example, highlands and uplands or densely forested zones and wetlands and a mosaic of ancestries rather than a genetically uniform CA and EBA Europe.

We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction, which then led to the establishment of fully developed pastoralism in the steppe by the end of the fourth millennium BC.

Gene flow from both contact zones into the steppe could also explain the small amounts of farmer-related ancestry in the emerging Yamnaya pastoralists, which differentiates them from the Steppe Eneolithic substrate and accounts for subtle geographical structure in the vastly expanding territory/range.
The early admixture during the Eneolithic presented in this study appears to be local to the northwestern Black Sea region of the fourth millennium bc and did not affect the hinterland in SEE.

The interaction between local and incoming groups in SEE did not result in archaeologically visible conflicts or a near-complete autosomal genetic turnover as observed in Britain or a replacement of the Y-chromosome lineages in the Iberian Peninsula

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The genetic cline observed in PCA reflects biological admixture between populations rather than other processes such as parallel selection or technical artefacts.
trigger_text: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors interpret the PCA cline as evidence of admixture without explicitly ruling out alternative explanations such as convergent evolution under similar selection pressures or systematic biases in SNP ascertainment.
implicit_arguments.notes: Standard assumption in archaeogenetics but worth noting

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The transfer of genetic material between populations was accompanied by the transfer of cultural innovations, technologies, and subsistence practices.
trigger_text: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc.
We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper demonstrates genetic admixture but uses this to infer cultural/technological transfer. The link between genetic exchange and innovation transfer is asserted rather than directly demonstrated with archaeological evidence of technology transfer in the sampled individuals.
implicit_arguments.notes: Key bridging argument connecting genetic to cultural findings

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The radiocarbon dates, despite potential freshwater reservoir effects, are sufficiently accurate to establish the temporal sequence of admixture events.
trigger_text: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates. However, accounting for this possibility, an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors acknowledge dating uncertainty but proceed with temporal interpretations. The assumption is that even with 500-year offsets, the chronological sequence remains valid for their argument about early contact.
implicit_arguments.notes: Dating uncertainty acknowledged but analytical conclusions maintained

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: Archaeological cultures (e.g., Cernavodă I, Usatove, Yamnaya) can be meaningfully associated with genetically distinct populations, allowing genetic data to inform cultural historical questions.
trigger_text: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous
BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex.

trigger_locations.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper repeatedly links archaeological culture labels with genetic ancestry patterns, assuming a correspondence between material culture and biological descent that is not always straightforward in archaeological theory.

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The absence of R1b-Z2103 Y-chromosome lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic males implies that the early contact involved different male lineages than those that later expanded with Yamnaya pastoralists.
trigger_text: Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors note the absence of specific Y-chromosome lineages but do not explicitly state the implication: that male-mediated gene flow during early contact differed from later Yamnaya expansion, possibly suggesting different social dynamics.
implicit_arguments.notes: Implications for sex-biased gene flow patterns

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The sampled individuals are representative of their respective populations and time periods, allowing generalisation from 135 individuals to population-level processes.
trigger_text: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Population-level claims are made based on samples from specific burial contexts (tells, cemeteries). The assumption that these individuals represent broader populations rather than elite or specific social groups is implicit.

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The HG ancestry resurgence in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE indicates interaction with remnant HG groups rather than preferential sampling of individuals with HG ancestry from a genetically diverse population.
trigger_text: EBA individuals from the fourth and third millennia bc from YUN and PIE do not show traces of steppe-like ancestry but instead a resurgence of HG ancestry observed widely in Europe during the fourth millennium bc
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The observation of increased HG ancestry is interpreted as a population-level 'resurgence' implying renewed contact with HG groups, but could alternatively reflect sampling of specific individuals or families with higher HG ancestry within a diverse population.

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The qpAdm modelling framework accurately captures the true admixture history, and alternative models with similar P-values represent genuinely plausible alternative histories rather than modelling artefacts.
trigger_text: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture

trigger_locations.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Multiple well-fitting models are presented as alternative scenarios, but the assumption that qpAdm accurately reflects biological reality (rather than mathematical fits to allele frequency patterns) is not explicitly stated.

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: If genetic homogeneity persisted across CA sites for centuries, then population replacement by genetically similar groups would be undetectable, making the absence of detected replacement consistent with either stability or invisible replacement.
trigger_text: given the near-identical genetic ancestry profiles of SEE CA groups, we caution that genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts, causing the replacement of one CA group by another.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors explicitly acknowledge this limitation but the logical consequence is that claims about sociopolitical stability based on genetic continuity are underdetermined by the evidence.

implicit_arguments.reconstructed_argument: The 1,240,000 SNP panel adequately captures population structure and ancestry proportions for the populations under study, despite being ascertained on modern populations.
trigger_text: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel)
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The 1240K panel is a standard tool in archaeogenetics, but its ascertainment on modern populations could introduce biases when studying ancient population structure. This is a standard disciplinary practice treated as unproblematic.

research_designs.verbatim_quote: To address this question, we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period.
research_designs.rationale: Fill spatial and temporal sampling gap to understand development between CA demise (~4250 BC) and pastoralist expansion (~3300 BC)
research_designs.notes: Core research design: archaeogenomic sampling to address temporal gap

research_designs.verbatim_quote: We compare these to Yamnaya-associated individuals from eastern Bulgaria, who were buried in mounds typically associated with steppe pastoralists during the third millennium BC and to individuals postdating the Usatove horizon in the northwestern Black Sea area.
research_designs.rationale: Compare newly sampled individuals to established reference groups to characterise genetic affinities
research_designs.notes: Comparative design linking new samples to known populations

research_designs.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21).
research_designs.rationale: Temporal stratification to trace genetic change over ~3000 years
expected_information_missing: sampling strategy rationale for site selection
research_designs.notes: Explicit temporal design spanning key transition period

research_designs.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected
research_designs.rationale: Use multiple analytical approaches (PCA, f-statistics, qpAdm) to validate ancestry findings

trigger_text: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc.

We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction, which then led to the establishment of fully developed pastoralism in the steppe by the end of the fourth millennium BC.
research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper's core argument connects genetic admixture evidence to cultural/technological transfer. This interpretation framework (genetic contact = innovation transfer) is not stated as an explicit research design objective but underlies the entire argument structure.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: The inferential leap from genetic admixture to technology transfer is not explicitly stated as an interpretive framework or hypothesis to be tested
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Affects how we evaluate the paper's claims about innovation transfer - the genetic evidence demonstrates contact but not technology exchange directly

research_designs.notes: Core interpretive framework linking genetic to cultural evidence

methods.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total. Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method and, for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out.
All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×.

Principal components were computed for 1,253 present-day western Eurasians from 77 different populations on which ancient individuals were projected, using the options 'lsqproject: YES' and 'shrinkmode: YES'.

Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations since the divergence from an African outgroup. The f4 and f3 statistics were calculated using qpDstat and the f4mode: YES function.
Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1)

All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment).
Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany
Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings. Background relatedness was estimated using the median value, across all sites per temporal group

The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis to prevent potential false positives
IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE

Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2). First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0 in BlastN mode
Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters. Briefly, bam files were trimmed 2 bp to remove ancient DNA damage.

The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years

trigger_text: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.
In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper processed 216 samples but reports 135 individuals. The selection criteria for which samples to attempt and which sites to include are not documented. Sample selection appears driven by collaborator access rather than systematic archaeological/temporal sampling design.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No documented criteria for site selection, sample prioritisation, or success threshold definition
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether sample represents the target population or is biased by access/preservation

trigger_text: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous
BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster, commonly associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex.

trigger_locations.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

methods.inference_reasoning: Individuals are associated with archaeological cultures (Cernavodă I, Yamnaya, Usatove) but the criteria for cultural attribution are not specified in Methods. Cultural associations appear to come from excavation context but the linkage methodology is undocumented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No documented criteria for associating individuals with archaeological cultures - burial context, grave goods, stratigraphy criteria not specified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess reliability of culture-individual associations that underlie core interpretations

protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method
for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out

DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64. DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment. For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries

Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture). Enriched libraries were sequenced on HiSeq4000 and NextSeq500 Illumina platforms using a single-read (SR 75) kit and sequencing 40 million reads for libraries between 0.1% and 2% or 20 million reads for libraries above 2%

After demultiplexing, EAGER v.1.92.56 was used to process raw ancient DNA sequence data. Raw reads were trimmed for Illumina adaptor sequences using AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0. Subsequently, reads were mapped to the human reference genome hs37d5 using BWA v.0.7.12 and duplicates were removed using DeDup v.0.12.1. The effect of postmortem DNA damage on genotyping was minimized by removing 2 bp from the 3′ and 5′ ends of reads from double-stranded UDG-half-treated libraries (n = 131) using the trimbam function included in bamUtils v.1.0.13. The resulting filtered bam files were genotyped with pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 by randomly calling one allele per position considering the human genome as a pseudohaploid genome (–randomHaploid).
protocols.notes: Consolidated sequence processing and genotype calling pipeline

consolidation_metadata.rationale: P05 (sequence processing) and P06 (damage trimming + genotyping) are sequential steps in a unified bioinformatic workflow

protocols.verbatim_quote: All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2.

For genome-wide analyses the new data from this study were merged with published ancient and modern data from the Allen Ancient DNA Resource (AADR) v.44.3... Data on the HO panel (around 600,000 SNPs) were used for PCA using the program 'smartpca' v.16000 (EIGENSOFT). Principal components were computed for 1,253 present-day western Eurasians from 77 different populations on which ancient individuals were projected, using the options 'lsqproject: YES' and 'shrinkmode: YES'. Individuals with fewer than 30,000 SNPs on the HO-dataset covered were excluded from the PCA.
The f3 and f4 statistics were calculated using the ADMIXTOOLS package. Standard errors were computed with the default block jackknife approach and 3 s.e. are reported and plotted.

The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG. Depending on the time period, the outgroup set was adjusted according to the specific test.
Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings.
The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis

IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE. We used HapBLOCK to perform the IBD sharing estimation... only shared blocks of more than 220 SNPs per centimorgan and shared blocks of more than 5 cM were kept for quality purposes

Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2). First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0 in BlastN mode and with semiglobal alignment type and default pipeline settings. The used database included all available complete bacterial and viral genomes as of 2017 in addition to selected eukaryotic pathogen genomes and the human reference sequence GRCh38.

parameters.database: RefSeq (bacterial + viral genomes 2017 + eukaryotic pathogens + GRCh38)

protocols.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters. Briefly, bam files were trimmed 2 bp to remove ancient DNA damage. We then determined genotype likelihoods from trimmed bam files using bcftools with the 1,000G panel (The 1,000 Genomes Project consortium) as a reference. We used GLIMPSE_impute on genomic chunks of 2,000,000 bp with the buffer size of 200,000 bp to perform imputation.

The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years. DATES measures the decay of ancestry covariance to infer the admixture time and estimates the variance of this admixture using a jackknife approach. The following parameters were used for every run: binsize 0.001; maxdis 1; qbin 10; lovalfit 0.45.

We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual, mapped this against the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix... The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD. Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling as described in ref. 70. HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup.
protocols.notes: Consolidated contamination estimation and uniparental haplogroup assignment

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Contamination estimation and haplogroup assignment are complementary authentication procedures assessed together

trigger_text: We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation and filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses
Individuals with fewer than 30,000 SNPs on the HO-dataset covered were excluded from the PCA.
Only samples with more than 0.5× coverage on the 1,240,000 positions (around 550,000 SNPs) after imputation were included in IBD analysis.
protocols.inference_reasoning: Multiple different SNP thresholds are applied for different analyses but the rationale for each threshold choice is not documented. Thresholds appear field-standard but justification for specific values is undocumented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No rationale for threshold values (30K, 400K, 550K SNPs) - why these specific cutoffs?
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess if thresholds are appropriate for the data quality distribution

protocols.notes: SNP thresholds stated but justification undocumented

trigger_text: The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG. Depending on the time period, the outgroup set was adjusted according to the specific test.
A detailed list of outgroups per test can be found in Supplementary Tables G, H, R, S, X and Y.
protocols.inference_reasoning: Outgroup selection is critical for qpAdm validity but rationale for choosing these specific outgroups is not documented. Selection criteria (geographic, temporal, genetic criteria) are referenced to supplementary tables but justification not in main Methods.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Rationale for outgroup selection and adjustment criteria not documented in main text
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Outgroup choice affects all ancestry modelling results - cannot assess if choices are appropriate

trigger_text: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture
Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic

trigger_locations.section: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

protocols.inference_reasoning: Multiple well-fitting models are presented as alternatives but protocol for choosing between competing models or interpreting model ambiguity is not documented. How do authors select which model to emphasise when multiple fit?

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No documented protocol for model selection when multiple models fit the data
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Affects interpretation - alternative models could support different historical scenarios

protocols.notes: Model selection criteria when multiple models fit

trigger_text: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates. However, accounting for this possibility, an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc
protocols.inference_reasoning: Freshwater reservoir effect acknowledged as potential source of dating error but no formal correction protocol is documented. The 500-year offset appears to be an estimate rather than formal correction.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No formal freshwater reservoir effect correction protocol - offset estimation approach not specified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Dating precision critical for temporal arguments about early contact

protocols.notes: Reservoir effect acknowledged but not formally corrected

author_orcids.notes: No ORCIDs found in PDF text. ORCIDs may exist in publisher metadata/CrossRef but not in extracted PDF content.

dataset_dois.description: DNA sequences deposited in European Nucleotide Archive

pid_graph_connectivity.notes: Paper DOI and ENA accession present. No ORCIDs in PDF, no software DOIs, no IGSN/RAiD.

funders.verbatim_text: This research was funded by the Max Planck Society
the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.)

data_availability.verbatim_statement: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.
data_availability.notes: Raw sequence data deposited in standard archaeogenetics repository

code_availability.notes: No code availability statement. Paper uses standard published software packages (ADMIXTOOLS, EAGER, GLIMPSE, etc.) with version numbers documented in Methods, but no custom analysis code repository provided.

author_contributions.verbatim_statement: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study. R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources. S.P. performed laboratory experiments. S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data. W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation. S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors.

conflicts_of_interest.verbatim_statement: The authors declare no competing interests.

ethics_approval.notes: No ethics statement. Ancient DNA studies on archaeological human remains typically require permissions from excavators/curators (covered in Methods) rather than formal ethics/IRB approval.

permits_and_authorizations.verbatim_statement: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.

permits.granting_authority: Site excavators, archaeologists, curators, museum directors (co-authors)
permits.details: Access permissions for archaeological samples from 8 sites across Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine, and Moldova

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Permissions integrated through co-authorship with material custodians - common practice in archaeogenetics

preregistration.notes: No preregistration mentioned. Not standard practice for archaeogenomics studies.

materials.description: Supplementary Tables A-Y referenced throughout for detailed data (sample information, f-statistics, qpAdm results, kinship, ROH, IBD, outgroups)
Supplementary Information sections 1-7 with expanded methods and results
Extended Data Figures 1-9 with additional analyses

references_completeness.notes: Comprehensive software citations with version numbers. Standard archaeogenetics reference dataset (AADR) used. 94 total references.

details.F1_pid: DOI present for paper; ENA accession for data
details.F2_rich_metadata: Paper metadata complete; data has minimal metadata in ENA
details.F3_pid_in_metadata: Paper DOI linked to ENA accession in text
details.F4_indexed: ENA is searchable; paper indexed in PubMed/Nature

details.A1_protocol: Open access paper (CC BY 4.0); ENA uses standard HTTP/FTP
details.A1_2_authentication: ENA data openly accessible without authentication
details.A2_metadata_persistence: ENA maintains metadata even if data withdrawn

details.I1_formal_language: Sequence data in standard formats (BAM, VCF implied)
details.I2_fair_vocabularies: ENA uses standard ontologies; paper uses archaeological culture names without controlled vocabulary
details.I3_qualified_references: Paper links data to ENA but lacks machine-readable linkage

details.R1_plurality_attributes: Paper well-documented; data has basic metadata
details.R1_1_clear_licence: Paper CC BY 4.0; ENA data licence unclear in paper
details.R1_2_provenance: Archaeological provenance detailed; analytical provenance documented
details.R1_3_domain_standards: Follows archaeogenomics standards (1240K panel, AADR compatibility)

fair_assessment.notes: Strong findability and accessibility due to Nature's open access model and ENA deposition. Interoperability limited by lack of controlled vocabularies for archaeological cultures and missing machine-readable PID linkages. No code repository reduces reusability score. Machine-actionability low due to manual integration requirements.

context_assessment.baseline_comparison: Above average for HASS-adjacent field; meets Nature's data sharing requirements but lacks code repository common in computational genetics

extraction_metadata.extraction_notes: Comprehensive infrastructure for Nature archaeogenomics paper. Strong data availability through ENA deposition. No code repository despite computational complexity. Permissions handled through co-authorship model common in archaeogenetics.

pass0_metadata.notes: Paper published in Nature. Full author list extracted from title page (29 authors). All authors listed with full names and institutional affiliations. DOI clearly visible on first page.

sections_processed: Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
pass1_claims_evidence.extraction_strategy: Liberal extraction following Pass 1 protocol. Processed paper section-by-section, extracting all potential evidence, claims, and implicit arguments. Nature format with main text + Methods section.
pass1_claims_evidence.notes: Complex archaeogenomics paper with extensive statistical analyses. Many claims supported by multiple lines of evidence (PCA, f-statistics, qpAdm modelling, IBD, ROH). Core thesis involves linking genetic evidence to cultural/technological transfer. Paper structure: main text presents results narratively with methods in separate section.

pass2_rationalization.notes: Pass 2 rationalization applied. Evidence consolidations: E01→E02 (granularity), E05→E53 (redundancy), E55+E56+E57→E55 (profile), E32+E33→E32 (compound finding). Claims consolidations: C33+C34+C35→C33 (compound interpretation). Cross-references updated. Implicit arguments unchanged as coverage was appropriate.

pass3_rdmap_explicit.extraction_strategy: Liberal explicit RDMAP extraction from Methods section. Extracted all documented strategic decisions (research designs), analytical approaches (methods), and specific procedural details (protocols) with verbatim quotes.
pass3_rdmap_explicit.notes: Comprehensive explicit RDMAP extraction. Paper has detailed Methods section typical of Nature papers with extensive procedural documentation. All items have explicit status and verbatim quotes from Methods.

pass4_rdmap_implicit.scan_methodology: Systematic 4-pattern scan across all major sections (Abstract, Introduction, Results, Discussion, Methods). Scanned for: (1) mentioned but undocumented procedures, (2) effects implying methodological causes, (3) tools/processes without specifications, (4) strategic positioning without explicit statement.
pass4_rdmap_implicit.notes: Nature paper with comprehensive Methods section. Implicit items primarily relate to: sample selection criteria, archaeological culture attribution methodology, threshold justifications, outgroup selection rationale, and model selection criteria. Paper exceptionally well-documented for laboratory and analytical procedures but less explicit about interpretive decisions.

pass5_rdmap_rationalization.notes: Conservative RDMAP rationalization. Main consolidations: (1) P05+P06 sequence processing workflow, (2) P17+P18+P19 authentication/haplogroup chain. Research designs and methods kept separate as they represent distinct assessable decisions. Paper has high-quality explicit documentation typical of Nature archaeogenetics papers.

pass6_infrastructure.notes: Complete infrastructure extraction. Paper meets Nature's data sharing requirements with ENA deposition. No code repository despite computational analyses.

schema_validator.notes: jsonschema package not installed - manual validation performed

pass7_validation.notes: Extraction validated successfully. All cross-references intact after bidirectional auto-correction. 100% linking rates across all entity types. All explicit items have verbatim quotes, all implicit items have trigger text. Infrastructure extraction complete with FAIR assessment.
